thread.title_full: Lorain County JVS chef Jordan Krystowski receives educator of the year award

author: Editorial staff
title: Lorain County JVS chef Jordan Krystowski receives educator of the year award
text:
Lorain County Joint Vocational School has announced that chef Jordan Krystowski, culinary arts instructor and a JVS alumnus, was named 2024 Chef Educator of the Year Award by the American Culinary Federation , according to a news release.
Krystowski, who has served as a culinary arts educator for the past six years, leads the American Culinary Federation-accredited culinary arts program at the JVS.
Under her leadership, students gain industry-recognized certifications, including the certified fundamental cook credential, and benefit from hands-on learning experiences that set the foundation for successful careers in the culinary industry, according to the release.
“Chef Krystowski’s dedication to her students and passion for culinary excellence are truly inspiring,” said Tina Pelto, principal at the JVS, in the release. “Her emphasis on hands-on learning and industry-relevant skills empowers our students to excel in their chosen paths and prepares them for success in the culinary field.”
A member of the Ohio Family, Career and Community Leaders of America Career Development Events Committee since 2022, Krystowski has consistently demonstrated her dedication to continuous program improvement and culinary education, according to the release.
Her mentorship has led students to compete and excel on national stages, the release said.
In 2023 and 2024, Krystowski coached students to SkillsUSA and Family, Career and Community Leaders of America national competitions, with a student earning a second-place finish at nationals, according to the release.
Beyond competitions, Krystowski enriches her students’ learning through guest chef demonstrations and community engagement.
From a three-day whole hog breakdown to a specialty diets demo, her efforts expose students to diverse culinary practices.
Also, her students have participated in American Culinary Federation meetings, community outreach events and fundraisers, the release said.
“Chef Krystowski exemplifies the impact of dedicated educators in shaping the next generation of professionals,” said Glenn Faircloth, superintendent of the JVS, in the release. “Her recognition by the (American Culinary Federation) underscores her role as a leader not only in our school, but in the broader culinary community.
“We are incredibly proud of her accomplishments.”
In addition to teaching, Krystowski has made notable appearances at community events, such as presenting fresh ravioli and hummus demonstrations, according to the release.
She also organized a successful pierogi fundraiser with her senior class, showcasing her ability to blend education with community engagement, the release said.
Krystowski holds a bachelor’s degree in education and actively pursues professional development through initiatives such as the American Culinary Federation Educators Summit, earning credits toward licensure, the release said.
Her achievements also were recognized with several accolades, including the American Culinary Federation President’s Award in 2023, according to the release.
